title: Former Boston Uber driver sentenced to 10 years on rape conviction
text:
Former Uber driver sentenced to prison after pleaded guilty to Dec. 2014 rape (Photo: Thomas Olivia, AFP/Getty Images)
2 CONNECT 3 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE BOSTON â€” A former Uber driver accused of raping a female passenger in 2014 and who is also linked to a series of assaults in Boston has been sentenced to 10 to 12 years in state prison, authorities said.
Alejandro Done, a 47-year-old Boston man, was sentenced Friday on charges of aggravated rape, kidnapping, and assault and battery, according to a press release from the office of a Massachusetts county District Attorney.
Done pleaded guilty to driving the female victim to a secluded location, trapping her in the car, and then strangling and sexually assaulting her on Dec. 6, 2014.
In a separate case, Done has also been charged in connection with five previously-unsolved sexual assaults in Boston between 2006 and 2010. This case is still pending, and is unrelated to Friday's sentencing.
USA TODAY
Former Uber driver linked to series of assaults in Boston
An Uber spokesman confirmed to USA TODAY that Done passed Uber's background check before he began working for the platform, and that the state of Massachusetts confirmed he had a clean record prior to his arrest. None of the incidents that occurred between 2006 and 2010 happened while Done was working for Uber, and the car the victim entered was not the one she requested off the app.
"This was a tragic incident and we were grateful to be able to assist police and prosecutors in identifying the perpetrator," said Uber spokeswoman Carlie Waibel.
A Massachusetts county District Attorney Marion Ryan encouraged the public to take precautions when using any ride-sharing service.
"While these apps are a modern convenience, they are not without their risks. Customers should make sure to verify license plates and car make and models before entering any vehicle, and remain active and aware of their surroundings," Ryan said in a Friday press release.
The way Uber conducts its background checks was a recent point of contention in the Massachusetts State House.
Four bills were discussed in the State House last month that would put state regulations on for-hire transportation companies, especially on the process used for background checks.
Uber currently uses a third-party service to conduct background checks. One bill proposed by Gov. Charlie Baker, would give the state oversight on the process used to check potential drivers. Uber has openly voiced its support for this bill.
Elsewhere in the U.S., Uber's problems are piling up. This weekend, Uber Drivers called for a nationwide strike against the ride-sharing service on a Facebook group called UBER Freedom. Protesters organized in cities such as San Francisco and Dallas to call for better wages and higher fares.
Earlier this year, a handful of drivers were granted class-action status on their lawsuits against the ride-hailing company after suing Uber on the grounds that they should be labeled employees and not independent contractors. In New York and Houston, taxi drivers have also openly argued that Uber is squeezing them out of a living wage.
